sen.j: 両面宿儺（りょうめんすくな）は上古、仁徳天皇の御世に飛騨国に現れたとされる妖怪である。
sen.e: Ryomen-sukuna is a specter that was said to appeared in Hida Province in ancient times, in the reign of Emperor Nintoku.
Ryomen-sukuna is a specter that was said to have appeared in Hida Province in ancient times, in the reign of Emperor Nintoku.
Ryomen-sukuna is a specter that was said to have appeared in Hida Province in ancient times, in the reign of Emperor Nintoku.

sen.j: その身体にはローマ神話のヤヌスのように頭の前後に顔が二つ付いており、おまけに腕が前後一対の四本、足も前後一対の四本あったとされる。
sen.e: Ryomen-sukuna had two faces on the front and back of its head, like Janus in Roman mythology, and two pairs of arms and two pairs of legs, each pair was on the front and back of the body.
Ryomen-sukuna had two faces on the front and back of its head, like Janus in Roman mythology, and two pairs of arms and two pairs of legs; each pair was on the front and back of the body.
Ryomen-sukuna had two faces on the front and back of its head, like Janus in Roman mythology, and two pairs of arms and two pairs of legs; each pair was on the front and back of the body.

sen.j: 背丈は1丈・18丈等様様（どちらにしても当時の日本人の平均身長より遥かに大きい）。
sen.e: The height varies from 3 to 54 meters depending on descriptions, but it was far taller than the average Japanese at that time anyway.
The height varies from 3.03 to 54.54 meters depending on descriptions, but it was far taller than the average Japanese at that time anyway.
The height varies from 3.03 to 54.54 meters depending on descriptions, but it was far taller than the average Japanese at that time anyway.

sen.j: 手には弓矢、剣を持っている。
sen.e: It had a bow, arrow, and sword in its hands.
It had a bow, arrow, and sword in its hands.
It had a bow, arrow, and sword in its hands.

sen.j: 動きは俊敏で怪力。
sen.e: It was quick-witted and had superhuman strength.
It was quick-witted and had superhuman strength.
It was quick-witted and had superhuman strength.

sen.j: 岐阜県高山市丹生川町（旧・大野郡丹生川村）の千光寺の本堂にある像は確かに頭の前後に顔が付いている武将像だが、同じ寺にある円空作のそれは笑いの顔の肩の上に怒りの顔が並んでいるという状態である。
sen.e: The statue in the main hall of Senko-ji Temple in Nyukawa-cho, Takayama City, Gifu Prefecture (former Nyukawa-mura, Ono County) is a busho (Japanese military commander) with faces on the front and back of the head; the statue by Enku in the same temple has an angry face on the shoulder with a smiling face.

The busho (Japanese military commander) statue in the main hall of Senko-ji Temple in Nyukawa-cho, Takayama City, Gifu Prefecture (former Nyukawa-mura, Ono County) has faces on the front and back of the head while another statue with a smiling face by Enku in the same temple has an angry face on its shoulder.

The busho (Japanese military commander) statue in the main hall of Senko-ji Temple in Nyukawa-cho, Takayama City, Gifu Prefecture (former Nyukawa-mura, Ono County) has faces on the front and back of the head while another statue with a smiling face by Enku in the same temple has an angry face on its shoulder.

sen.j: 『日本書紀』に拠ると、飛騨国に現れ、朝廷に背いて民衆を苦しめていたが、仁徳天皇65年、朝廷が差し向けた武将・武振熊命（たけふるくまのみこと）により退治されたとされている。
sen.e: According to "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), Ryomen-sukuna appeared in Hida Province where he disobeyed the Imperial court and suffered people, but in 377 the Imperial court sent a military commander Takefurukuma no mikoto to expel Ryomen-sukuna from the province.

According to "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), Ryomen-sukuna appeared in Hida Province where he disobeyed the Imperial court and made people suffer, but in 377 the Imperial court sent a military commander, Takefurukuma no Mikoto, to expel Ryomen-sukuna from the province.

According to "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), Ryomen-sukuna appeared in Hida Province where he disobeyed the Imperial court and made people suffer, but in 377 the Imperial court sent a military commander, Takefurukuma no Mikoto, to expel Ryomen-sukuna from the province.

sen.j: 『日本書紀』では朝敵として悪者扱いを受けているが、飛騨国のみならず、美濃国でも英雄、恩人と考えられ、信仰の対象となっている。
sen.e: While "Nihonshoki" described Ryomen-sukuna as a villain and Emperor's enemy, people in Hida and Mino Provinces treated Ryomen-sukuna as a hero and benefactor and worshipped him.
While "Nihonshoki" described Ryomen-sukuna as a villain and an enemy of the emperor, people in Hida and Mino Provinces treated Ryomen-sukuna as a hero and benefactor and worshipped him.
While "Nihonshoki" described Ryomen-sukuna as a villain and an enemy of the emperor, people in Hida and Mino Provinces treated Ryomen-sukuna as a hero and benefactor and worshipped him.

sen.j: 高山市丹生川町（旧・大野郡丹生川村）の千光寺や善久寺は、両面宿儺を開基としており、両面宿儺は飛騨国に仏教を伝えたとされている。
sen.e: Ryomen-sukuna is regarded as Kaiki (patron of a temple in its founding) of Senko-ji Temple and Zenkyu-ji Temple in Nyukawa-cho, Takayama City, Gifu Prefecture (former Nyukawa-mura, Ono County), and it is said that he introduced Buddhism to Hida Province.

Ryomen-sukuna is regarded as Kaiki (patron of a temple at its founding) of Senko-ji Temple and Zenkyu-ji Temple in Nyukawa-cho, Takayama City (former Nyukawa-mura, Ono County), and it is said that he introduced Buddhism to Hida Province.
sen.cmt: took out ", Gifu Prefecture" (extra info)preposition check
sen.e: Ryomen-sukuna is regarded as Kaiki (patron of a temple at its founding) of Senko-ji Temple and Zenkyu-ji Temple in Nyukawa-cho, Takayama City (former Nyukawa-mura, Ono County), and it is said that he introduced Buddhism to Hida Province.

sen.j: 飛騨国、美濃国の多くの古寺でも両面宿儺を信仰の対象としている。
sen.e: In many other old temples in Hida and Mino Provinces, Ryomen-sukuna is worshipped.
In many other old temples in Hida and Mino Provinces, Ryomen-sukuna is worshipped.
In many other old temples in Hida and Mino Provinces, Ryomen-sukuna is worshipped.

sen.j: また、飛騨国一之宮である水無神社は位山を神体山とするのだが、祭神ははっきりしていないことから、両面宿儺が隠された祭神とする説もある。
sen.e: Hidaichinomiya Minashi-jinja Shrine has been worshipping Kuraiyama Mountain as Shintaizan (a mountain worshiped as the sacred dwelling place of a deity or deities), but its enshrined deity is unknown, so a theory states that Ryomen-sukuna is a hidden deity of the shrine.

Minashi-jinja Shrine, which is the ichinomiya (the highest-ranked shrine in the area) in Hida Province, has been worshipping Kuraiyama Mountain as shintaizan (a mountain worshiped as the sacred dwelling place of a deity or deities), but its enshrined deity is unknown, so a theory states that Ryomen-sukuna is a hidden deity of the shrine.
sen.cmt: wording change for 飛騨国一之宮
sen.e: Minashi-jinja Shrine, which is the ichinomiya (the highest-ranked shrine in the area) in Hida Province, has been worshipping Kuraiyama Mountain as shintaizan (a mountain worshiped as the sacred dwelling place of a deity or deities), but its enshrined deity is unknown, so a theory states that Ryomen-sukuna is a hidden deity of the shrine.

sen.j: 一説では両面宿儺は双生児や兄弟の象徴であり、古代史での双生児、大碓命小碓命（つまり日本尊命とその兄）のことという。
sen.e: One theory states that Ryomen-sukuna is a symbol of twins and siblings, therefore it refers to Oousu no Mikoto and Osu no Mikoto (i.e. Yamato takeru no mikoto and his brother), a twin in the ancient Japanese history.

One theory states that Ryomen-sukuna is a symbol of twins and brothers, therefore it refers to Oousu no Mikoto and Ousu no Mikoto (i.e. Yamato Takeru no Mikoto and his brother), twins in ancient Japanese history.
sen.cmt: rule from sunflare's mypage:｢小碓命」とスペルが同じになってしまうため、指定表記ルールの例外とするgrammar/ vocab
sen.e: One theory states that Ryomen-sukuna is a symbol of twins and brothers, therefore it refers to Oousu no Mikoto and Ousu no Mikoto (i.e. Yamato Takeru no Mikoto and his brother), twins in ancient Japanese history.

sen.j: また、別の説では仲哀天皇皇子の）かご坂皇子忍熊王兄弟という。
sen.e: Another theory states that Ryomen-sukuna refers to Emperor Chuai's sons, Kagosaka no miko and Oshikuma no mikoto.
Another theory states that Ryomen-sukuna refers to Emperor Chuai's sons, Kagosaka no Miko and Oshikuma no Mikoto.
Another theory states that Ryomen-sukuna refers to Emperor Chuai's sons, Kagosaka no Miko and Oshikuma no Mikoto.

sen.j: どちらも美濃国飛騨国に関係が深い。
sen.e: Both of brothers deeply related to Mino and Hida Provinces.
Both of pairs of brothers are deeply related to Mino and Hida Provinces.
Both of pairs of brothers are deeply related to Mino and Hida Provinces.

sen.j: 竹内文書では飛騨国は"日玉国""日霊国"で記され、飛騨が高天原であり、位山がピラミッドと考えている。
sen.e: Takeuchi-monjo (an ancient text which recorded the lineage of ancient kami and a dynasty preceding Emperor Jinmu) described Hida Province as "日玉国" or "日霊国," indicating that Hida was Takamanohara (plain of high heaven) and Kuraiyama Mountain as the Pyramid.

Takeuchi-monjo (an ancient text which recorded the lineage of ancient kami and a dynasty preceding Emperor Jinmu) wrote Hida Province as "日玉国" or "日霊国," indicating that Hida was Takamanohara (plain of high heaven) and Kuraiyama Mountain was the Pyramid.

Takeuchi-monjo (an ancient text which recorded the lineage of ancient kami and a dynasty preceding Emperor Jinmu) wrote Hida Province as "日玉国" or "日霊国," indicating that Hida was Takamanohara (plain of high heaven) and Kuraiyama Mountain was the Pyramid.

sen.j: 両面宿儺は飛騨を拠点とした大和朝廷に匹敵する国があったと考えられている。
sen.e: It is considered that Ryomen-sukuna had a Hida-based dynasty comparing with Yamato Dynasty.
It is considered that Ryomen-sukuna had a Hida-based dynasty the same size as the Yamato Dynasty.
It is considered that Ryomen-sukuna had a Hida-based dynasty the same size as the Yamato Dynasty.

sen.j: 六十五年、飛騨国有一人。
sen.e: In year 65, there was a man in Hida Province.
In the year 65, there was a man in Hida Province.
In the year 65, there was a man in Hida Province.

sen.j: 曰宿儺。
sen.e: He was named Sukuna.
He was named Sukuna.
He was named Sukuna.

sen.j: 其為人、壱体有両面。
sen.e: The man had a single head and torso with two faces,
The man had a single head and torso with two faces,
The man had a single head and torso with two faces,

sen.j: 面各相背。
sen.e: Each face oriented in opposite directions.
Each face oriented in opposite directions.
Each face oriented in opposite directions.

sen.j: 頂合無項。
sen.e: Two faces met at the top but had no nape.
The two faces met at the top but had no nape.
The two faces met at the top but had no nape.

sen.j: 各有手足。
sen.e: Each face was served by its own set of appendages.
Each face was served by its own set of appendages.
Each face was served by its own set of appendages.

sen.j: 其有膝而無膕踵。
sen.e: Each had knees but no ankles.
Each had knees but no ankles.
Each had knees but no ankles.

sen.j: 力多以軽捷。
sen.e: He had tremendous power but still could move quickly.
He had tremendous power but still could move quickly.
He had tremendous power but still could move quickly.

sen.j: 左右佩劒、四手並用弓矢。
sen.e: With two pairs of arms he held swords, a bow and an arrow.
With two pairs of arms he held swords, a bow and an arrow.
With two pairs of arms he held swords, a bow and an arrow.

sen.j: 是以、不随皇命。
sen.e: The Sukuna refused to comply with imperial directives.
Sukuna refused to comply with imperial directives.
Sukuna refused to comply with imperial directives.

sen.j: 掠略人民為楽。
sen.e: He threatened and plundered the people.
He threatened and plundered the people.
He threatened and plundered the people.

sen.j: 於是、遣和珥臣祖難波根子武振熊而誅之。
sen.e: Whereupon the emperor dispatched the founder of Wanibe no omi Naniwaneko takefurukuma to vanquish the creature.
Whereupon the emperor dispatched the founder of Wanibe no omi Naniwaneko Takefurukuma to vanquish the creature.
Whereupon the emperor dispatched the founder of Wanibe no omi Naniwaneko Takefurukuma to vanquish the creature.

sen.j: 高山市丹生川町（旧・大野郡丹生川村）の特産品の野菜として、宿儺かぼちゃがある。
sen.e: One of special products of Nyukawa-cho, Takayama City (former Nyukawa-mura, Ono County) is a pumpkin called Sukune Kabocha,
One of the special products of Nyukawa-cho, Takayama City (former Nyukawa-mura, Ono County) is a pumpkin called Sukune Kabocha.
One of the special products of Nyukawa-cho, Takayama City (former Nyukawa-mura, Ono County) is a pumpkin called Sukune Kabocha.

sen.j: 関連については今のところ不明だが、近畿地方の和歌山市千塚古墳群にある大日山35墳（6世紀前半）から前後両面の人物埴輪（頭部のみ）が出土して話題となった。
sen.e: Although its relevance is still unknown, it was in the news that a haniwa figure of a man (only its head) with two faces, on front and back, was excavated from Dainichiyama No.35 Mound (early 6th century) in Senzuka burial mounds in Wakayama City, Kinki region.

Although its relevance is still unknown, it was in the news that a man-shaped haniwa (clay figure) (only its head) with two faces, on front and back, was excavated from Dainichiyama No.35 Mound (early 6th century) from the Senzuka burial mounds in Wakayama City, Kinki region.

Although its relevance is still unknown, it was in the news that a man-shaped haniwa (clay figure) (only its head) with two faces, on front and back, was excavated from Dainichiyama No.35 Mound (early 6th century) from the Senzuka burial mounds in Wakayama City, Kinki region.

sen.j: この両面埴輪は貴人埴輪に多い下げ角髪をしている。
sen.e: This two-face haniwa had braids which was common in nobility haniwa.
This two-faced haniwa had mizura (a hair style with the hair parted down the center and each side, left and right, tied in a figure 8), which was common among the hanima of nobility.
This two-faced haniwa had mizura (a hair style with the hair parted down the center and each side, left and right, tied in a figure 8), which was common among the hanima of nobility.
